question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
There exists a scalar $c$ so that
\[\mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) + \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) = c \mathbf{v}\]for all vectors $\mathbf{v}.$  Find $c.$
inference:
Let $\mathbf{v} = \langle v_1, v_2, v_3 \rangle.$ Then
\begin{align*} \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) &= \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{i} \times v_1 \mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} \times v_2 \mathbf{i} + \mathbf{k} \times v_3 \mathbf{i}) \\ &= \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{i} \times \mathbf{i}) v_1 + \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{i} \times \mathbf{j}) v_2 + \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{i} \times \mathbf{k}) v_3 \\ &= \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{i} \times \mathbf{i}) v_1 + \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{0}) v_2 + \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{-j}) v_3 \\ &= \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{0}) v_1 + \mathbf{0} v_2 + \mathbf{k} v_3 = \mathbf{k} v_3. \end{align*}Similarly,
\begin{align*} \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) &= \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) \\ &= \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{i} \times v_1 \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{j} \times v_2 \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k} \times v_3 \mathbf{j}) \\ &= \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{0}) v_1 + \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{0}) v_2 + \mathbf{j} \times (-\mathbf{i}) v_3 \\ &= \mathbf{0} v_1 + \mathbf{0} v_2 + (-\mathbf{k}) v_3 = -\mathbf{k} v_3. \end{align*}Also,
\begin{align*} \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) &= \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) \\ &= \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{i} \times v_1 \mathbf{k} + \mathbf{j} \times v_2 \mathbf{k} + \mathbf{k} \times v_3 \mathbf{k}) \\ &= \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{-j}) v_1 + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{i}) v_2 + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{0}) v_3 \\ &= \mathbf{j} v_1 + (-\mathbf{i}) v_2 + \mathbf{0} v_3 \\ &= \mathbf{j} v_1 - \mathbf{i} v_2. \end{align*}Therefore,
\begin{align*} \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) + \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) &= \mathbf{k} v_3 - \mathbf{k} v_3 + \mathbf{j} v_1 - \mathbf{i} v_2 \\ &= \mathbf{j} v_1 - \mathbf{i} v_2 = \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) + \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) = \langle -v_2, v_1, 0 \rangle. \end{align*}This is $2\mathbf{v}.$  Thus $c = 2.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{2}$
ground_truth:
In general, the vector triple product states that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$
\[\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}.\]So
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) &= (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} = \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}, \\
\mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) &= (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} = \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
\mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) &= (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{k}) \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k} = \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}.
\end{align*}Hence,
\begin{align*}
&\mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) + \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) \\
&= 3 \mathbf{v} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\
&= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{v} = 2 \mathbf{v}.
\end{align*}Thus, $c = \boxed{2}.$

question:
Let $\mathbf{v} = \langle v_1, v_2, v_3 \rangle.$ Then
\begin{align*} \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) &= \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{i} \times v_1 \mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} \times v_2 \mathbf{i} + \mathbf{k} \times v_3 \mathbf{i}) \\ &= \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{i} \times \mathbf{i}) v_1 + \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{i} \times \mathbf{j}) v_2 + \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{i} \times \mathbf{k}) v_3 \\ &= \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{i} \times \mathbf{i}) v_1 + \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{0}) v_2 + \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{-j}) v_3 \\ &= \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{0}) v_1 + \mathbf{0} v_2 + \mathbf{k} v_3 = \mathbf{k} v_3. \end{align*}Similarly,
\begin{align*} \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) &= \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) \\ &= \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{i} \times v_1 \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{j} \times v_2 \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k} \times v_3 \mathbf{j}) \\ &= \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{0}) v_1 + \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{0}) v_2 + \mathbf{j} \times (-\mathbf{i}) v_3 \\ &= \mathbf{0} v_1 + \mathbf{0} v_2 + (-\mathbf{k}) v_3 = -\mathbf{k} v_3. \end{align*}Also,
\begin{align*} \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) &= \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) \\ &= \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{i} \times v_1 \mathbf{k} + \mathbf{j} \times v_2 \mathbf{k} + \mathbf{k} \times v_3 \mathbf{k}) \\ &= \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{-j}) v_1 + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{i}) v_2 + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{0}) v_3 \\ &= \mathbf{j} v_1 + (-\mathbf{i}) v_2 + \mathbf{0} v_3 \\ &= \mathbf{j} v_1 - \mathbf{i} v_2. \end{align*}Therefore,
\begin{align*} \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) + \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) &= \mathbf{k} v_3 - \mathbf{k} v_3 + \mathbf{j} v_1 - \mathbf{i} v_2 \\ &= \mathbf{j} v_1 - \mathbf{i} v_2 = \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) + \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) = \langle -v_2, v_1, 0 \rangle. \end{align*}This is $2\mathbf{v}.$  Thus $c = 2.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{2}$

inference:
Let $\mathbf{v} = \langle v_1, v_2, v_3 \rangle.$ We want to compute $\mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) + \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k})$.

Using the vector triple product, $\mathbf{u} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{w}) = (\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{w}) \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{w}$, we have
\begin{align*} \mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) &= (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} \\ &= (1) \mathbf{v} - (v_1) \mathbf{i} \\ &= \langle v_1, v_2, v_3 \rangle - \langle v_1, 0, 0 \rangle \\ &= \langle 0, v_2, v_3 \rangle. \end{align*}Similarly,
\begin{align*} \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) &= (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} \\ &= (1) \mathbf{v} - (v_2) \mathbf{j} \\ &= \langle v_1, v_2, v_3 \rangle - \langle 0, v_2, 0 \rangle \\ &= \langle v_1, 0, v_3 \rangle. \end{align*}and
\begin{align*} \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) &= (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{k}) \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k} \\ &= (1) \mathbf{v} - (v_3) \mathbf{k} \\ &= \langle v_1, v_2, v_3 \rangle - \langle 0, 0, v_3 \rangle \\ &= \langle v_1, v_2, 0 \rangle. \end{align*}Then
\begin{align*} &\mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) + \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) \\ &= \langle 0, v_2, v_3 \rangle + \langle v_1, 0, v_3 \rangle + \langle v_1, v_2, 0 \rangle \\ &= \langle v_1, v_2, v_3 \rangle + \langle v_1, v_2, v_3 \rangle = 2\mathbf{v}. \end{align*}Thus $c=2$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{2}$
ground_truth:
In general, the vector triple product states that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$
\[\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}.\]So
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) &= (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} = \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}, \\
\mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) &= (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} = \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
\mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) &= (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{k}) \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k} = \mathbf{v} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}.
\end{align*}Hence,
\begin{align*}
&\mathbf{i} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{i}) + \mathbf{j} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{j}) + \mathbf{k} \times (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{k}) \\
&= 3 \mathbf{v} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\
&= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{v} = 2 \mathbf{v}.
\end{align*}Thus, $c = \boxed{2}.$
